description:
Allofournierella massiliensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from a human stool sample collected in Marseille, France. It is a Gram-negative, anaerobic, non-spore-forming, non-motile, rod-shaped bacterium.

Phylogenetically, Allofournierella massiliensis belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes, class Bacteroidia, order Bacteroidales, and family Bacteroidaceae. Genome analysis has revealed that it has a circular chromosome with a size of approximately 3.9 Mbp and a G+C content of around 43%.

This species is considered a member of the normal human gut microbiome and has been found to be present in relatively low abundance in healthy individuals. Its exact role and function within the complex gut ecosystem are still under investigation, but it is believed to be involved in various metabolic processes and interactions with other gut microbes.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological and potential clinical significance of Allofournierella massiliensis in the human gut microbiome.
